commit_message:
Improve ODL configuration

Configure automatically ODL version based on the package version
rather than maintain a hardcoded version.

This has caused many issue while package version differs with the variable
set.

Closes-Bug: 1784784
Change-Id: I15da5d2583b5727942d598d183cc481f0e33d0e6
(cherry picked from commit 6e17f942b59c35e65d883e4f1dabb5da7ec3e1aa)

commit_message:
Increase CI job timeout to 2 hours

If there is a change to kolla then images are built, which can push the
job over the existing 1.5 hour timeout. These jobs are also used in the
kolla CI.

Change-Id: I88a28745cf834376163ced36984c317fce831346

commit_message:
Use with statement to enforce file close

We found some race conditions at overcloud deploy, looks like after
running 55-heat-config, the -notify.json files are not there yet.

This review enforce a close() of the file with a with statement

Closes-Bug: 1792343

Change-Id: I9b72d4b1356aaf22364007163d47b0e2bd862549

commit_message:
import zuul job settings from project-config

This is a mechanically generated patch to complete step 1 of moving
the zuul job settings out of project-config and into each project
repository.

Because there will be a separate patch on each branch, the branch
specifiers for branch-specific jobs have been removed.

Because this patch is generated by a script, there may be some
cosmetic changes to the layout of the YAML file(s) as the contents are
normalized.

See the python3-first goal document for details:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/stein/python3-first.html

Change-Id: I421f513f39922332f5b5899b476bd245321a86a3
Story: #2002586
Task: #24342

commit_message:
Move ovsdbapp jobs to its tree

This patch is moving the legacy CI jobs for ovsdbapp into its tree. This
will give the project more flexibility to control what jobs should run
in which pipeline as well as facilitate creation/deletion/updates for
new and existing jobs.

Change-Id: I2e34bd16ab9907bdc3f9225b879f9b0846d2c779

commit_message:
Clean up role tests

Now that we're using the general templates, we can slim down
the role test definitions. We can also remove tests which are
not being watched, or which are fundamentally broken. With
this we can also remove unused scripts/plays.

We do the following:

1. We remove the 'upgrade' job, given that it's been broken
   all cycle due to the way the job executes and we need to
   regroup to figure out another way to do it.
2. We rename the tox target for 'func_lxc' to 'lxc' and
   as the 'func_' prefix is pointless.

Change-Id: Ie0e72f69026c44a3c3ff6316bbb308bdd873c149
(cherry picked from commit f6ab8c4a8af15caba9d73fbcce95d18a76514cfc)

commit_message:
Return sizes of storage devices

Properties implemented in all storage resources to return sizes
of all available storage devices.

Change-Id: Ieb374f8cabb0418bb2680fdab690446346fc354f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sushy refs/changes/64/600664/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: _drives_sizes = None _volume_sizes = None def get_max_drive_size_bytes(self, up_to_bytes=None): """Max size available (in bytes) among all device resources. Optionally capped by `up_to_bytes` value. Returns the cached value until it (or its parent resource) is refreshed. """ if self._drives_sizes is None: self._drives_sizes = [ storage_.drives_max_size_bytes for storage_ in self.get_members() ] return utils.max_safe(drive_size for drive_size in self._drives_sizes if (up_to_bytes is None or drive_size <= up_to_bytes)) """Max size available (in bytes) among all device resources. Returns the cached value until it (or its parent resource) is refreshed. """ return self.get_max_drive_size_bytes() def get_max_volume_size_bytes(self, up_to_bytes=None): """Max size available (in bytes) among all volume resources. Optionally capped by `up_to_bytes` value. Returns the cached value until it (or its parent resource) is refreshed. """ if self._volume_sizes is None: self._volume_sizes = [ storage_.volumes.max_size_bytes for storage_ in self.get_members() ] return utils.max_safe(volume_size for volume_size in self._volume_sizes if (up_to_bytes is None or volume_size <= up_to_bytes)) """Max size available (in bytes) among all volume resources. Returns the cached value until it (or its parent resource) is refreshed. """ return self.get_max_volume_size_bytes() self._drives_sizes = None self._volume_sizes = None
deleted_lines: _max_drive_size_bytes = None _max_volume_size_bytes = None """Max size available (in bytes) among all device resources.""" if self._max_drive_size_bytes is None: self._max_drive_size_bytes = max( storage_.drives_max_size_bytes for storage_ in self.get_members()) return self._max_drive_size_bytes """Max size available (in bytes) among all Volumes under this.""" if self._max_volume_size_bytes is None: self._max_volume_size_bytes = max( storage_.volumes.max_size_bytes for storage_ in self.get_members()) return self._max_volume_size_bytes self._max_drive_size_bytes = None self._max_volume_size_bytes = None

commit_message:
Switch to stestr

According to Openstack summit session [1],
stestr is maintained project to which all Openstack projects should migrate.
Let's switch to stestr as other projects have already moved to it.

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/YVR-python-pti

so we remove the whole process.

subject: Use role defaults for lxc_cache_prep_timeout
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-09-23 23:27:42.000000000', 'files': ['releasenotes/notes/lxc-cache-prep-timeout-97dc18882f7b1e76.yaml', 'tasks/lxc_cache_preparation.yml', 'defaults/main.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-lxc_hosts/commit/5be42a58ff1ffc3ff19d60ae1830d60b771b9ab3', 'message': 'Use role defaults for lxc_cache_prep_timeout

In https://review.openstack.org/523525 the default value was
changed for SuSE and CentOS to be higher, but the value was
also overridden using role vars which have a high precedence.

This patch ensures that the value uses the role defaults to
ensure it has the lowest precedence. It also changes the reno
to ensure that the change in default is communicated.

The increased timeout will have no real effect on gating, but
will benefit installations where the mirror is a bit slow.

Change-Id: I41a68313d1841d14001acca591db5c5638e53ffc
(cherry picked from commit b634afe2046e0d4914bac711adbc6b0d9c134b4f)
'}]
commit_message:
Use role defaults for lxc_cache_prep_timeout

In https://review.openstack.org/523525 the default value was
changed for SuSE and CentOS to be higher, but the value was
also overridden using role vars which have a high precedence.

This patch ensures that the value uses the role defaults to
ensure it has the lowest precedence. It also changes the reno
to ensure that the change in default is communicated.

The increased timeout will have no real effect on gating, but
will benefit installations where the mirror is a bit slow.

Change-Id: I41a68313d1841d14001acca591db5c5638e53ffc
(cherry picked from commit b634afe2046e0d4914bac711adbc6b0d9c134b4f)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-lxc_hosts refs/changes/63/604663/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
import zuul job settings from project-config

This is a mechanically generated patch to complete step 1 of moving
the zuul job settings out of project-config and into each project
repository.

Because there will be a separate patch on each branch, the branch
specifiers for branch-specific jobs have been removed.

Because this patch is generated by a script, there may be some
cosmetic changes to the layout of the YAML file(s) as the contents are
normalized.

See the python3-first goal document for details:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/stein/python3-first.html

Story: #2002586
Task: #24315

Delegate the database schema import to monasca_db_setup_host

In order to remove the requirement to install the MariaDB client
libraries on all monasca hosts, we need to isolate all DB actions
on monasca_db_setup_host which has those libraries.

commit_message:
WIP: Course Policy check in middelware

A look at how to have baseline policy check across all services, so new
service specific roles can be added and used in a more manageable way.

Change-Id: I4040df4afec107635d9b06a3ce513532b4329036
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone-specs refs/changes/39/453739/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================== Coarse Policy Checks in Middleware ================================== TODO: add blueprint link Currently, when a user has any role in a project, they automatically get full access to most services in the system. This blueprint talks about how we transition to place where if by default users have no access to any of the services, by using policy checks in keystonemiddleware. Problem Description =================== Today if you have any role in a project you get read and write access to most endpoints in the system. This is particularly confusing when you consider adding a "nova_observer" or "cinder_observer" role to a user and you get write access to neutron. Proposed Change =============== We add an extra check to keystone middleware to ensure a user passes a policy check before they are allowed access to any authenticated parts of the API, any bits of the API protected by keystone middleware. It will work something like this: * after we get the token information, we do a policy check * check if the context.roles includes at least one of the roles that have access to at least one API. A good default would be: ``role:Member or role:admin`` This is done by doing a policy check. * keystone middleware looks in oslo.policy for the rule name "api_access" and if not present defaults to the above default. This gives us protection for projects not using oslo.policy, but also allows project that set policy defaults in code to set a sensible default in their code base that matches their other in code defaults. TODO: Some APIs need to work without authentication, those APIs don't get the role check. We need to help operators deal with upgrade. If needed they can override the check to "@" so they can slowly work out how to turn on these checks. Alternatives ------------ We could try and add these checks in each of the services, across all APIs, but that is messy and long winded. We could look at doing more policy checks in middleware, but then it starts to fight the existing in-code policy (and scope) checks. Security Impact --------------- Better to default to closed. Notifications Impact -------------------- None Other End User Impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ Its a small extra check of existing information. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- Across upgrade care will be need for a smooth transition to restricting the access to all projects by default. When adding extra roles in the policy.json, need to know also consider modifying the rule that talks about these base checks. Developer Impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: TBD Other contributors: OSIC Work Items ---------- * implement new * document what needs to happen in install documentation Dependencies ============ None. Documentation Impact ==================== Need to describe to operators how to use this problem. References ========== None

commit_message:
WIP Write down my ideas around delegation

I think we need to look at the use case of a service that runs onto of a
keystone protected service, doing things on behalf of the existing user,
such as creating instances to run databases (Trove)

Change-Id: I35245b45f1eb9630a6599a9f61dec28f7e6a22cc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone-specs refs/changes/29/455629/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================== Least privilege delegation ========================== TODO - bp link A look at the authorization problems relating to applications that run on top of services that use keystone, such as Trove using resources in Nova, Neutron and Cinder. Problem Description =================== Lets define several actors in this story: * Operator: they run the cloud, and have installed Magnum but not Trove. * Bill payer: they pay for the resources being used in the cloud. * Developer: they use resources in the cloud, and run Trove in the cloud. Lets look at some key observations about this future system: * Developer often creates a sub project within their own project for each system they deploy. They can set quota on the sub project to ensure it sticks within its budget. The usage for each sub project is itemised in the bill that the bill payer gets at the end of each month, so they know which of their customer to bill. * Magnum and heat are installed by the operator. They are granted permission by the operator to create resources on behalf of cloud users, in a way that they get a single bill for all the resources they use, never exceeding there existing quota. This is used by the developer to deploy containers in several of the projects they are working in, but not all of their projects. * Trove is run on the cloud by the developer to provide several database clusters for some projects they are working on. The developer has given Trove access to some of the private networks in their projects, to connect the database into their application deployed with Magnum. * The developer deploys some of their own workloads on a customers private OpenStack cloud. They programmatically work out they have been given access to in the private system, so its easy to ask for any more permissions they may need to run their application. They note they depend on snapshots being available, so they can't use the flavor of instance that doesn't support snapshots. Its also a slightly newer version of the cloud than they are using internally, but all the same APIs works as expected. A separate cloud operator hears about all these great features that are available to users on the latest version, and chooses to upgrade their cloud to take advantage of these features. However they have already customized the policy.json file to give users observer vs full access roles. They want a smooth transition to the new dynamic permissions. Lets discuss things that have not changed in the above picture: * Every access token has a specific level of access within a given project. There are no per resource limits. * It assumes strong support for hierarchical tenants within all the services, including support for hierarchical quotas. * We support a smooth upgrade path between releases. Breaking it down to make progress --------------------------------- Lets first reduce the scope of the problem, and dig deeper. Trove needs to create an instance connected to a user's private network. The user should not be able to destroy the instance, but it should use their quota, and be billed like any other resource they use. Inside the instance, it needs to have access to barbican to get the certificate being used to protect the database cluster communications. This is stored under an identity that is specific to the instance. The data for this member of the DB cluster is being stored on a cinder volume that the user can snapshot, and then export the snapshot, to help with taking a crash consistent snapshot of the system. The user ideally can restrict the amount of resources the Trove system is allowed to help them budget what is going on. We need to do all this and maintain the principal of least privilege. Proposed Change =============== The user experience could be a bit like this: * Developer asks Trove to request required access to project X * Developer goes to keystone to grant requested access. This creates a sub project of project X and gives Trove a new API key to access that project with the requested permissions. * Developer gives the new sub project access to the neutron network they want trove to use. * Trove is now free to create an instance to host the database on the correct network. Note by default there is no other users that has access to the project that trove has, unless the developer creates such a user. Also note that the Developer's user in the parent project only has access to view the instances in that project, by default. And admin in that parent project could have access to delete those instances in the child project, but the developer would not regularly use that user, because that would violate the principle of least privilege. In many clouds the developer may not be given that level of access, as the operator controls the users in that sub project. * Developer reviews quota usage and sees trove using three instances for the cluster in the given subproject. * Developer now revokes create instance access from Trove, so the API key trove is using can no longer create new instance, but can delete the existing instances as required. Should trove need the additional access, it will register a request for that access with keystone. TODO.... Alternatives ------------ Per service concepts of a resource being "protected" by a service: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/438134/ But this seems like a very piecemeal approach to the problem. There are lots of other alternatives... I have not written any other up yet. Security Impact --------------- Lots of impact. Notifications Impact -------------------- TODO Other End User Impact --------------------- TODO Performance Impact ------------------ TODO Other Deployer Impact --------------------- TODO Developer Impact ---------------- TODO Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- TODO... Primary assignee: <launchpad-id or None> Other contributors: <launchpad-id or None> Work Items ---------- TODO Dependencies ============ * hierarchical quotas Documentation Impact ==================== Lots References ========== TODO

commit_message:
WIP: more context around the garbutt model

Added context on the usecases that drive me to think about quota a set
of sub trees you set limits on, and how that helps with delegating the
issuing of quotas.

Its a bit more complicated than I hoped, some of the holes spotted so
far are highlighted.

Change-Id: Ie186f001cf017e9a669fb6175eebb708e30e06d9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone-specs refs/changes/93/446993/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Use case G1: Large community/private cloud ------------------------------------------ You are an operator of a large cloud. It is jointed funded by two large departments. So you want to split resources between those folks based on how much they paid towards the cloud. You also hold back some resources to allow for live-migrations during maintenance, for quick machine swaps, and a few VMs the operators use run some automation. * Department A: 10 * Department F: 10 * Admin reserve space P: 10 (not realistic, but whatever, keeps it consistent) The operator allows department A and department F to set their own quota, and trusts the system to ensure the whole sub tree of projects never go over that limit (assuming they are not already over that limit when the limit is applied, in that case they are not allowed to add anything until they drop under that limit, as you would expect). Now department A has most of its resources used by project B, and it allows project B to set the quota between its two groups C and D. It does that by giving a user in project B admin permissions (not global admin, but project only admin). All the time, this operator makes sure the sum of all the root projects is never greater than the amount of available capacity in the system. As new capacity is added, it is handed out to the department that funded it. Use case G2: Public cloud ------------------------- This cloud is always adding resources to give the appearance of infinite capacity. It used quotas to limit the risk of a customer not paying their bill at the end of the month. Sometimes if a customer pre-pays they increase the quota, as the risk is now limited. Sometimes a customers wants their limits decreased so because they don't want someone going crazy on their personal credit card, and they don't trust their scripting. Anyway, the public cloud only monitors and bills based on the root tenant of any hierarchy, in this case A, F and P. The invoice, however, likely includes a breakdown for each subtree and how much they contributed to the overall bill. This operator has a default quota of 10, and allows any user to create lots of sub tenants and users, that could use some of their quota. In this cloud, there is no concerns about the fact they only have enough capacity for building 15 things, because when 10 things are built they will light up more capacity before 15 things have been built, and so on. (lets just assume lots of extra projects and zero so that makes sense, but whatever). Worked example 1 ---------------- - The default limit in the system applies to any project that has no parent, i.e. is a root project.- At all times, when there is a limit set on any subtree, the system must ensure the whole subtree never exceeds that limit. - When setting limits on a child, it drops the effective (local) limit on the parent project (so the parent doesn't starve out its children) So with a Default limit of 10, the system looks like this:Consider the limit checks that must be applied here: * Creating a resource in project P. We must count all the resources in project P and ensure they don't exceed the limit 10. * Creating a resource in project G (or project F), we must count all the resources in projects F and G, they must not add up to more than 10. * Creating a resource in project D (or A, B, or C) we must count all the resources being used by project A, B, C and D and ensure they do not exceed the limit of 10. Looking back at the above use cases, the only difference here is on how the operator is choosing to hand out more or less resource limits than the number of resources currently available within the system. Worked example 2 ----------------- We start right after example 1, but now the admin of project A allows there to be an admin in project B that can assign quota. Firstly, project B is given this quota by the admin of project A: ``UPDATE LIMIT on B to 5`` .. blockdiag:: blockdiag { orientation = portrait; A -> B -> C; B -> D; F -> G; A [label="A (10, ll=5)"]; B [label="B (5, ll=5)"]; C [label="C (-1)"]; D [label="D (-1)"]; F [label="F (10, ll=10)"]; G [label="G (-1)"]; P [label="P (10, ll=10)"]; } Lets consider creating some resources, and what checks need to be made: * Creating resources in projects F, G and P are unchanged. * Creating resources in project D (or B or C) now must count all the resources used by projects B, C and D and check not over limit of 5. * Creating resources in project A, we count all the resources from project A only, and ensure they do not exceed the 5. (The above is wrong, the fix comes later...) Re-consider example 2 --------------------- Lets add resource usage into the mix, but look at just the A sub tree: .. blockdiag:: blockdiag { orientation = portrait; A -> B -> C; B -> D; A [label="A (l=10, ll=10, usage=2)"]; B [label="B (l=-1, usage=4)"]; C [label="C (l=-1, usage=1)"]; D [label="D (l=-1, usage=1)"]; } Now we apply: ``UPDATE LIMIT on B to 5`` .. blockdiag:: blockdiag { orientation = portrait; A -> B -> C; B -> D; A [label="A (l=10, ll=5, usage=2)"]; B [label="B (l=5, usage=4)", textcolor="#00aa00"]; C [label="C (l=-1, usage=1)"]; D [label="D (l=-1, usage=1)"]; } If we apply the rules above, we note that: * A has a usage of 2, and thus is allowed to create 3 more resources * B has a total subtree usage of 4+1+1=6, so users of B, C and D are unable to create any resources. * But, now A can create 3 resources, which means the whole subtree has a resource usage of 11, pushing it over the limit of 10. * Boom, the admin of project A has a way to bypass its limit. Conclusion: the previous worked example is total nonsense, we need to do more checks to fully implement our rule system. Fixed worked example 2 ---------------------- We start right after example 1, but now the admin of project A allows there to be an admin in project B that can assign quota. Firstly, project B is given this quota by the admin of project A: ``UPDATE LIMIT on B to 5`` .. blockdiag:: blockdiag { orientation = portrait; A -> B -> C; B -> D; F -> G; A [label="A (10, ll=5)"]; B [label="B (5, ll=5)"]; C [label="C (-1)"]; D [label="D (-1)"]; F [label="F (10, ll=10)"]; G [label="G (-1)"]; P [label="P (10, ll=10)"]; } Lets consider creating some resources, and what checks need to be made: * Creating resources in projects F, G and P are unchanged. * Creating resources in project D (or B or C) now must count all the resources used by projects B, C and D and check not over limit of 5. We need to also do a second limit check. We must count all the resources used by A, B, C and D, and check we are not over the limit of 10. * Creating resources in project A, we count all the resources from project A only, and ensure they do not exceed the 5. We need to also do a second limit check. We must count all the resources used by A, B, C and D, and check we are not over the limit of 10. * Note: there is a lot of counting needed for the above checks, but also note the second check only needs to count the projects not counted in the first check, and add that to the totals from the first check. Its still kinda terrible, but needed to enforce the safe delegation if you allow applying quota limits to a sub tree that is using more than that limit already. Then the admin of project B decides to add a limit to project C only: ``UPDATE LIMIT on C to 2`` .. blockdiag:: blockdiag { orientation = portrait; A -> B -> C; B -> D; F -> G; A [label="A (10, ll=5)"]; B [label="B (5, ll=3)"]; C [label="C (2)"]; D [label="D (-1)"]; F [label="F (10, ll=10)"]; G [label="G (-1)"]; P [label="P (10, ll=10)"]; } Lets consider creating some resources, and what checks need to be made: * Creating resources in projects F, G and P are unchanged. * Creating a resource in project C, we must count all the resources in project C and ensure they do not exceed 2. We need a second limit check to ensure projects B, C and D to not exceed the limit 5. We also need a third check to ensure project A, B, D and D to not exceed the limit 10. * Creating a resource in project D (or project B) must now count all the resources in projects B and D and ensure they do not exceed the limit of 2. We need a second limit check to ensure projects B, C and D to not exceed the limit 5. We also need a third check to ensure project A, B, D and D to not exceed the limit 10. * Creating a resource in project B must now count all the resources in project B and ensure they don't exceed the limit of 3. We need a second limit check to ensure projects B, C and D to not exceed the limit 5. We also need a third check to ensure project A, B, D and D to not exceed the limit 10. * Creating a resource in project A must now count all the resources in project A, and ensure they do not exceed the limit of 5. We need a second limit check to ensure project A, B, D and D to not exceed the limit 10. Those checks are enough to ensure the limits for each sub tree with a limit our correctly enforced. Worked example 3 ---------------- We start right after example 1 again. The admin of project A again allows project B to set quota on its children. Now it decides to add a limit of 10 on project C, which is valid given our rules, and we get something like this:They have to understand they get their quota from a port shared out by project A and that is currently empty because of the amount handed out to children. Question: Should we only allow projects to set their own quota if they have a limit enforced? Does that make things any easier to understand? Maybe? TODO: if we dropped support for the "-1" child quota, does this help at all? Worked example 4 (relax local limit rules) ------------------------------------------ TODO: what about if drop the idea of a local limit, and we get D and C having more quota added together than B. That is probably OK, but a bit confusing: .. blockdiag:: blockdiag { orientation = portrait; A -> B -> C; B -> D; F -> G; A [label="A (10)"]; B [label="B (5)"]; C [label="C (4)"]; D [label="D (3)"]; F [label="F (10)"]; G [label="G (-1)"]; P [label="P (10)"]; } * Creating resources in projects F, G and P are unchanged. * Creating a resource in project C, we must count all the resources in project C and ensure they do not exceed 4. We need a second limit check to ensure projects B, C and D to not exceed the limit 5. We also need a third check to ensure project A, B, D and D to not exceed the limit 10. * Creating a resource in project D we must now count all the resources in projects D and ensure they do not exceed the limit of 3. We need a second limit check to ensure projects B, C and D to not exceed the limit 5. We also need a third check to ensure project A, B, D and D to not exceed the limit 10. * Creating a resource in project B, we have to count all the resources in project B, C and D to ensure they are under the limit of 5. We then have to count all the resources in projects A, B, C, D and ensure we are under the limit of 10. Note, this works out simpler than considering a local limit, but it means it possible for project B to use up all the resources, and not leave anything for C and D. That is probably bad.
deleted_lines: - When setting limits on a child, it drops the effective (local) limit on a parent. Default limit of 10In a default closed scenario, the moment there is a default quota all children would have to have 0 quota, as there is not a sensible value for them to have otherwise.

commit_message:
Addressing the challenges of a global community

At the SWG session at the Atlanta PTG, a clear theme was making the
contributor experience more inclusive of the whole global community.

This attempts to build on recent fantastic contributions in the
documentation contributor guide, looking at issues with language and
culture differences that existing within our global community.

Note: this is not complete or exhaustive, its just a starting point
for others to start documenting what has worked and what as failed,
and making people aware of the things you can do to make our
communication more accessible to the whole of our global community.

Change-Id: Ia1e85518cdeeae874ea9e9fa6538f469df0a8579
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-team-guide refs/changes/23/441923/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ================ Global Community ================ OpenStack is a global community. For our design and development to be truly Open, we must be welcoming to people from across the globe. Working hours ============= Not everyone is awake at the same time of day, and we are not all working at the same time of day. We need to be aware of this, and structure our community so it doesn't favor those that are awake during the peak time where the most people in the community are awake. In a similar way, not everyone works full time on OpenStack. Those operating clouds must be responsive to their customer's requests for support over the need to update an active code review. In either case, participation in the community should not require big sacrifices. Culture ======= Every contributor is heavily influenced by their local culture. Things that seem as simple as saying yes or no are handled very differently in different cultures. When it comes to giving feedback and debating ideas, the differences are even larger. Language ======== OpenStack projects communicate in English, and our documentation is written in US English. At the same time, for a large number of our contributors English is not their native language, nor is the language they usually use at work. All native English speakers must be aware of the problems this can create for non-native English speakers when reading, writing, listening and speaking. The documentation contributor guide has lots more information on the problems that can be faced and looks at some ways around those problems: https://docs.openstack.org/contributor-guide/non-native-english-speakers.html A lot of those ideas are based on the wonderful talk given by Masayuki Igawa, Dong Ma, and Samuel De Medeiros Queiroz at linux.conf.au in 2017. You can watch their original talk on YouTube: `Non-native English speakers in Open Source communities: A True Story <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fsn6buk-BtE>`_ or read their article on opensource.com: `Tips for non-native English speakers working on open source projects <https://opensource.com/article/17/1/non-native-speakers-take-open-source-communities>`_. Situations and Solutions ======================== In this section we look at some common situations and how best to ensure we remain inclusive to people from all over the globe in those situations. In-Person Gatherings -------------------- OpenStack makes use of in person gatherings (such as the PTG, Forum and Ops Midcycle). One great use of those is high bandwidth conversations to help build consensus on design decisions. We must consider how people can feel excluded from these events: * Not everyone can be there. There are many reasons, be it family commitments, budget, or being advised medically to not fly on planes. * Remote participation may not be practical. The event may happen at the time you are usually sleeping, or the internet connection has too much latency or too little bandwidth. * You maybe be unable to follow the conversation that is happening. Some of the solutions that have helped in the past: * Provide summaries of the discussion. Good for those that couldn't follow that conversation, where in another session at that time, or were unable to attend. * Make proposals not decisions. Making a firm decision in person excludes those unable to join with that in person discussion. Instead write up the proposal and use an asynchronous mechanism to make the decisions, such as a reviewing a written specification in gerrit. TODO IRC Meetings ------------ TODO Code Reviews ------------ TODO E-mail ------ TODO All interactions ---------------- TODO

commit_message:
Spec on preemptible servers

This covers only the first phase of the work, focusing on the scheduler
being able to call out to a reaper to free up space for non-preemtable
instances by deleting some preemtable instances.

Sometimes called spot instances, these are a way for users to use
"spare" capacity in your could, beyond what there regular quota
would allow them to use.

This can help increase the utilization of your cloud, while
still trying to give a fair share of resources using quotas with no
overcommit.

More details are discussed:
http://openstack-in-production.blogspot.co.uk/2018/02/maximizing-resource-utilization-with.html

APIImpact
blueprint preemptible-instances

Based on a previous spec: Ide101ac64afefae4597e2a191b45ac51dc2fb9bb
Co-Authored-By: Alvaro Lopez Garcia <aloga@ifca.unican.es>

Change-Id: Id25fc512827c995f3bcc53b2ff027d073d4dde3e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/40/438640/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Preemptible Instances Support ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/preemptible-instances Cloud computing may give users the illusion of infinite capacity, but it is not always like that. When the resources are full and a request can not be satisfied an error is returned to the users. In some cases, there are tasks that can be interrupted (i.e. they are fault tolerant) to leave room to other tasks, such as batch processing tasks, but not only. Problem description =================== While large cloud often add capacity as demand increases, giving the appearance of infinite capacity, most smaller clouds have a fixed set of resources. Both want to get the maximum utilization our of their existing hardware investments. Preemptable servers help with that. For smaller clouds, you can use quota to give a reserved amount of capacity to each department (or project). So you ensure you never hand out more quota than available capacity in the system. This ensures each department gets a fair share of resources. In additional, you probably reserve a certain amount of capacity for maintenance such as needing to reboot and live-migrate between hosts. While this is all very commendable, it leave a large chunk of resources idle. If there were a way of running a server, such that it uses the space reserved for another user, or indeed the space reserved for maintenance. Should the space ever be required, the server will be deleted to make space for the higher priority server. In larger clouds its more normal to give out much more quota than the resources are available. However, some clouds have models of being able to pay for reserved instances. This spec does not deal with this more complicated concept, we deal only with marking instances as preemptible, assuming that all other instances are consuming some kind of "reserved" amount. Large public clouds are likely to instead want a three their system of reserved, standard and preemptible. This is not something we are aiming to fix in this spec, it is left as future work. TODO - reference new quota system that has tools to help ensure you don't hand out more capacity than you have quota. The end user of a preemptible server want to: * not get surprised when a server is deleted after several weeks of use, so its best to ensure the server is automatically deleted after 24 hours to stop any miss-use of these more temporary VMs * they want warning they are about to get killed, as such its expected that a soft delete signal will be sent to signal the VM its above to be deleted. If the soft delete doesn't respond after 30 seconds, a hard delete should be issued so not to delay the resources that are needed for other users. * preemptible resources consume regular quota if available, otherwise they consume a separate preemptible quota (which defaults to the same amount as their regular quota). Should more regular instances be created, it may mean the preemptible then starts using preemptible quota. The scheduling rules could be very complicated for preemptible servers. In this version we need should limit ourselves to the following constraints: * preemptible allocations are ignored when deciding where it is possible to place a regular allocation * should both a preemptible allocation slot get the same ranking as an empty slot, the empty slot should be preferred * should two preemptible allocation slots get the same ranking, we should prefer firstly preemptible allocations belonging the project that is creating the request, and then the most recently created preemptible allocation Use Cases ---------- While nova currently has no concept of reserving capacity, it is possible to use the quota system in a way that ensures you only hand out quota for resources that are available in your cloud. Scientific Computing ******************** In HPC like environments, there is often infinite work and finite capacity, while leads to people being able to make good use of these sorts of resources. While wanting to maximize the utilization of their infrastructure, it is quite common that they need to satisfy two kind of requests: batch processing and interactive sessions (for example for interactive analysis of results). As an example, consider a scientific cloud infrastructure with two kind of users: users from group-A requiring interactive tasks that need to be spawned in a short period of time (used for analysis and visualization) and group-B that require large amounts of computing power for data analysis (that is, traditional HTC, normally executed on a batch system). This use case will require that the operators set a static partitioning of the resources for both user groups, since group-B's requests may fill up the complete infrastructure for long periods of time, making impossible to satisfy requests coming from group-A. With the preemptible instances in place, request from group-B would run as preemptible instances, being aware that they can be stopped at a given point and filling up as much resources as they can. Afterwards, an incoming request from group-A would stop some of the running instances if there is no room for them. OpenStack CI ************ Currently, a provider has to allocate resources for this task and the step is a little bit high. With preemptible instances, infrastructure donors will be able do provide resources just with the already available hosts when they are not used by customers. OpenStack Infrastructure team could use many providers and deal with a large volatile capacity Clearly this is also useful for internal QA teams that want to run large test runs overnight on hardware that is not currently being used by the department that might be paying for that hardware. Not a batch system ******************* Note that we are not here creating a system that executes the batch work on preemptible servers, rather we are creating preemptible servers that can be used by a batch system. Such a system could look to run queued work when the system is no longer as busy as it was during the day. We could have scale groups where it tried to keep a target number of preemptible workers in the face of those workers being delete by the system. Note this has been long established here: https://docs.openstack.org/developer/nova/project_scope.html#iaas-not-batch-processing Future ideas ************ We should start by adding the simplest cases. But for completeness, we are excluding doing things like this, for this first version: * Running preemptible reGet users to shutdown their interactive VMs at the end of the day, have automation to help with that. Could boot preemptible VMs (that are boot from volume) to use the space not used by the other running VMs. Calling start on an instance would cause the preemptible VMs to be deleted in the usual way, before starting the instance back up. * In some environments, workstations could reboot into a nova-compute worker when it is know for workstations to be used, e.g. in classrooms. The worker could advertise that it can only run preemptible workloads. Once the user requests the workstation, it the force host down is called, and all the preemptible VMs on the box will be deleted in the usual way. Proposed change =============== There are several parts to the proposed change here: * Placement extended to deal with absolute and preemptible allocations * Ability to create preemptable allocations * If querying inventory for absolute allocations, ignore preemptable allocations, only consider them when querying for preemptable allocations * When returning an inventory with a related preemptable allocation, return a list of them (including project_id and created_at) * Scheduler weighers that read the preemptible allocations returned from placement, as noted above. * Conductor, after claiming from placement, can issue the delete command for any preemptible server that need to be removed to make room for a non-preemptible server * VM Expiration of preemptible instances (similar to auto unrescue), in a periodic task on the compute node. Ensure no preemptible instance runs for more than 24 hours. Alternatives ------------ A clear alternative is implementing this outside of Nova. What I have proposed here is what I believe is the minimal information we need to give Nova for a batch processing system to be built on top of Nova, where you use the existing quota and reporting systems tied to Nova. If we were to have the concept of a preemptive instance outside of Nova, it would require a separate API to expose the concept, and you end up wrapping most of the Nova API in a way that is likely to lead to lots of strange proxy API problems, and a divergence of the Nova API. Data model impact ----------------- TODO REST API impact --------------- A new microversion to add "preemptible: True" flag when creating a server. This should also appear on a detailed server list and a server show. TODO. Security impact --------------- There is a possible denial of service for preemptible instances, as pointed by Daniel Berrange: Somebody could request a large number of non-preemptible instances, causing many preemptible instances to be destroyed, then they could just immediately shut down their non-preemptible instances again. They wouldn't have incurred any real expense for the short time their non-preemptible instances run, but they will have killed off many other people's preemptible instances. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- The end users will have a new type of instance type to take into consideration and they should be aware that any preemptible instance can be stopped at a given point, without further advise. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- TBD Developer impact ---------------- TBD Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: aloga Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- TBD Dependencies ============ TBD Testing ======= TBD Documentation Impact ==================== TBD References ========== A proof of concept is available in [1] [1] https://github.com/indigo-dc/opie/ [2] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/spot-instances [3] http://openstack-in-production.blogspot.com.es/2016/04/resource-management-at-cern.html [4] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/scientific-wg-austin-summit-agenda History ======= Optional section for Mitaka intended to be used each time the spec is updated to describe new design, API or any database schema updated. Useful to let reader understand what's happened along the time. .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Pike - Introduced

commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: I9a9228b0caf4d8eefc1bc020b8b9bb32dfab583d

commit_message:
import zuul job settings from project-config

This is a mechanically generated patch to complete step 1 of moving
the zuul job settings out of project-config and into each project
repository.

Because there will be a separate patch on each branch, the branch
specifiers for branch-specific jobs have been removed.

Because this patch is generated by a script, there may be some
cosmetic changes to the layout of the YAML file(s) as the contents are
normalized.

See the python3-first goal document for details:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/stein/python3-first.html

Change-Id: I9a295f2773fda26ccb9707360129a9d1c618ed7f
Story: #2002586
Task: #24342

commit_message:
WIP - Abstract file and directory operations in replicator/reconstructor

The replicator and reconstructor call functions from the 'os' and
'shutil' modules. This patch pushes these functions (listdir, rmtree..)
to the DiskFileManager.

This helps avoid code duplication for alternate diskfile
implementations.

This needs test, but I'd like feedback about the idea.

Change-Id: Ia72872cd9ee6bdacfc2f2cb546c6f11ca6961fd5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/02/602402/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import shutilfrom os.path import basename, dirname, exists, join, splitext, isdir, isfile def exists(self, path): """ :param path: full path to directory """ return os.path.exists(path) def mkdirs(self, path): """ :param path: full path to directory """ return mkdirs(path) def listdir(self, path): """ :param path: full path to directory """ return os.listdir(path) def rmtree(self, path, ignore_errors=False): """ :param path: full path to directory :param ignore_errors: if True, ignore errors from failed removals, else, raise an exception. """ return shutil.rmtree(path, ignore_errors) def remove_file(self, path): """ :param path: full path to directory """ return remove_file(path) def remove(self, path): """ :param path: full path to directory """ return os.remove(path) def isdir(self, path): """ :param path: full path to directory """ return isdir(path) def isfile(self, path): """ :param path: full path to directory """ return isfile(path) def rmdir(self, path): """ :param path: full path to directory """ return os.rmdir(path)
deleted_lines: from os.path import basename, dirname, exists, join, splitext

commit_message:
Avoid tox_install.sh

Instead of using tox-install.sh, we can install neutron now directly from pypi
- or use the current branch in CI system using tox-siblings.

Update tox.ini for this change and add neutron to
requirements file.

Conflicts:
	requirements.txt
	tools/tox_install.sh
	tox.ini

Change-Id: I416acf75c3db3cdf202a6bc49d96d1abb73b2d6e
(cherry picked from commit 9443e4e7a252347cd0bdb57e66ec51e3c8aaae3f)

commit_message:
Deploy TLS overcloud in fs051 (sc000 upgrade job)

When upgrading from Queens to Rocky, we deal with a change of
default. Queens is non-TLS by default and Rocky is TLS by default.

We can't upgrade from non-TLS to TLS, so let's try from TLS to TLS
first. We'll have to make non-TLS to non-TLS working too.

Change-Id: Iaa0bf370421fb93bd8410503f6ee0b29d088bd0d
Related-Bug: #1771567
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart refs/changes/43/568843/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

We need to set EnablePublicTLS to false in order to prevent Rocky
tripleo-common workflow from automatically generating TLS parameters

This parameter has no meaning for Queens templates, so it should be

Closes-Bug: #1771567
"}]
commit_message:
[Queens only] Allow mixed version deployment of scenario000

We need to set EnablePublicTLS to false in order to prevent Rocky
tripleo-common workflow from automatically generating TLS parameters
which would break basic mixed-version deployment.

This parameter has no meaning for Queens templates, so it should be
safe. It's there just to alter tripleo-common behavior, which detects
its presence in Rocky.

Change-Id: I253b26bd8187c7f4ad4c9881de1ce73578a6e669
Closes-Bug: #1771567
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/36/569136/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Prevent trying to enable TLS when upgrading
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-05-17 11:48:38.000000000', 'files': ['templates/overcloud_upgrade_prepare.sh.j2', 'templates/overcloud_upgrade_converge.sh.j2', 'defaults/main.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-upgrade/commit/551b34322d648aed1b23a0e506a92649c74218e9', 'message': "Prevent trying to enable TLS when upgrading

On queens, deployments were non-TLS by default, on Rocky, they're TLS
by default. It's not valid to go from non-TLS to TLS during
upgrade. When we're upgrading a non-TLS environment, we need to append
an environment file to prevent trying to switch to TLS (and breaking).

Change-Id: Ia2e296a8e824c68bcc54713d60064cfd3273dbb2
"}]
commit_message:
Prevent trying to enable TLS when upgrading

On queens, deployments were non-TLS by default, on Rocky, they're TLS
by default. It's not valid to go from non-TLS to TLS during
upgrade. When we're upgrading a non-TLS environment, we need to append
an environment file to prevent trying to switch to TLS (and breaking).

Change-Id: Ia2e296a8e824c68bcc54713d60064cfd3273dbb2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-upgrade refs/changes/93/569093/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Specific to Q->R upgrade -- if we're not upgrading TLS deployment, # we need to pass special env file. upgrade_tls_enabled: false

commit_message:
import zuul job settings from project-config

This is a mechanically generated patch to complete step 1 of moving
the zuul job settings out of project-config and into each project
repository.

Because there will be a separate patch on each branch, the branch
specifiers for branch-specific jobs have been removed.

Because this patch is generated by a script, there may be some
cosmetic changes to the layout of the YAML file(s) as the contents are
normalized.

See the python3-first goal document for details:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/stein/python3-first.html

Change-Id: I1bb09765c0a76d672dac42492feca22773a9e237
Story: #2002586
Task: #24342

commit_message:
Ceilometer meters for ODL should use project id of admin

OpenDaylight v2 driver should set project_id as the uuid of the
tenant owning the port for port meters and admin tenant id for switch,
switch.port and table meters. The admin tenant id should be fetched from
keystone.

Change-Id: I728770c058604d786d2e59addc6793a9c0e8e0d8
Signed-off-by: Deepthi V V <deepthi.v.v@ericsson.com>
(cherry picked from commit f5140781a374d3dc7a2a1715d91b908c513e383a)

subject: Avoid double root-marker
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-09-12 08:17:32.000000000', 'files': ['playbooks/publish/install-guide.yaml', 'playbooks/publish/deploy-guide.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/1d2bc1fad901d5ddd80e0cf81b8280876fceea28', 'message': 'Avoid double root-marker

prepare-for-afs includes already the root-marker wirter, an extra
write-root-marker is not needed and wrong - we currently end with
stable/queens job having two root-markers:
html/.root-marker
html/queens/.root-marker

Remove the extra root-marker.

Change-Id: I9a7de9ec372266b3b6dcd650b69f1ec401ef0b0c
'}]
commit_message:
Avoid double root-marker

prepare-for-afs includes already the root-marker wirter, an extra
write-root-marker is not needed and wrong - we currently end with
stable/queens job having two root-markers:
html/.root-marker
html/queens/.root-marker

Remove the extra root-marker.

Change-Id: I9a7de9ec372266b3b6dcd650b69f1ec401ef0b0c

commit_message:
Follow devstack-plugin-ceph job rename

The devstack-plugin-ceph jobs have migrated to zuul v3
& in-repo and renamed[1], this commit use the new job.

This patch rename job for openstack/glance only as other
place is taken care in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/601032/
Patch removing old job from openstack-infra/openstack-zuul-jobs[2]
[1] https://review.openstack.org/543048
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/601316/

Change-Id: Ief8eb739ae0c5185c36dedf786b269b609de8209

revisions:

... when creating an image from a running VM.

If there is a backingStore in the XML definition of the file, use its
format type instead of the type of the disk itself.

We have to do this, because we use qcow2 overlay files if the source

Closes-Bug: #1793351

commit_message:
Really use source image format as default for snapshot_image_format

... when creating an image from a running VM.

If there is a backingStore in the XML definition of the file, use its
format type instead of the type of the disk itself.

We have to do this, because we use qcow2 overlay files if the source
image is of format raw.

Change-Id: Id494be1ee5a77bd02b33354236ff2f99eeeb55d7
Closes-Bug: #1793351
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/55/603855/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def get_disk_type_from_backing_file(guest): """Retrieve disk type (raw, qcow2, lvm, ploop) of backingStore""" guest_config = guest.get_config() format_type = None disk = next(d for d in guest_config.devices if isinstance(d, vconfig.LibvirtConfigGuestDisk)) format_type = disk.backing_store.format_type return format_type

  ...

commit_message:
Fix typo in upgrade playbook's name.

Fix typo to avoid error when wrong playbook is referenced:
  openstack overcloud upgrade run \
    --stack overcloud --roles Controller \
    --playbook post_upgrade_steps_playbooks.yaml
  ...
  u'ERROR! playbooks must be a list of plays'

Change-Id: I2a02d567bbc9e95c198d8cfe3e368d97b43be9a9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient refs/changes/63/603363/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fix syntax for set_fact module.

Fix issue that arise during upgrade:
 error while evaluating conditional (redis_pcs_res|bool):
  'redis_pcs_res' is undefined

Change-Id: I4298eb1ec2fc0e0c44aa63189cff3962fb06c6bd

commit_message:
Use templates for cover and lower-constraints

Small cleanups:

* Use openstack-tox-cover template, this runs the cover job
  in the check queue only. Remove individual cover jobs.
* Use openstack-lower-constraints-jobs template, remove individual
  jobs.
* Sort list of templates

Change-Id: I1d5b7401f880fa071d9e6312eb7d414050c9ece4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sushy refs/changes/50/604550/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from collections import namedtuple import eventlet from fuxi_kubernetes.common import constants from fuxi_kubernetes.provisioner.watch_framework import cache as store_cache from fuxi_kubernetes.provisioner.watch_framework import delta_fifo from fuxi_kubernetes.provisioner.watch_framework import reflector ResouceEventHandler = namedtuple('ResouceEventHandler', 'on_add, on_delete, on_update') class Controller(object): def __init__(self, resource_type, key_func, lw, watch_timeout, resource_event_handler): self._cache = store_cache.Cache(None) self._fifo = delta_fifo.DeltaFIFO(key_func, self._cache) self._reflector = reflector.Reflector( resource_type, lw, watch_timeout, self._fifo) self._cache.set_key_func(self._fifo.keyof) self._resource_event_handler = resource_event_handler self._running = False def stop(self): self._reflector.stop() self._running = False def start(self): self._reflector.start() def _f(): while self._running: _, resource_event = self._fifo.pop() if not resource_event: eventlet.sleep(1) continue self._process_resource_event(resource_event) self._running = True eventlet.spawn(_f) def _process_resource_event(self, resource_event): add_update_events = [ constants.WATCH_EVENT_TYPE_ADDED, constants.WATCH_EVENT_TYPE_MODIFIED, constants.WATCH_EVENT_TYPE_SYNC ] handler = self._resource_event_handler cache = self._cache action, resource = resource_event if action in add_update_events: old, exists = cache.get(resource) if exists: cache.update(resource) handler.on_update(old, resource) else: cache.add(resource) handler.on_add(resource) elif action == constants.WATCH_EVENT_TYPE_DELETED: cache.delete(resource) handler.on_delete(resource)

added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from oslo_service import service from fuxi_kubernetes.provisioner import controller class Service(service.ServiceBase): def __init__(self): self._controller = controller.Controller() def start(self): self._controller.start() def stop(self): self._controller.stop() def wait(self): self._controller.wait() def reset(self): pass

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """Base provision plugin""" from abc import ABCMeta from abc import abstractmethod import six class VolumeOption(object): """Option for provisioning pv""" __slots__ = ('pv_reclaim_policy', 'pv_name', 'pvc', 'parameters') def __init__(self, pv_reclaim_policy, pv_name, pvc, parameters): """Init an instance of VolumeOption :param pv_reclaim_policy: string :param pv_name: string :param pvc: kubernets.V1PersistentVolumeClaim :param parameters: dict """ self.pv_reclaim_policy = pv_reclaim_policy self.pv_name = pv_name self.pvc = pvc self.parameters = parameters @six.add_metaclass(ABCMeta) class ProvisionPlugin(object): @abstractmethod def provision(self, volume_option): """Provision a new pv :param volume_option: VolumeOption :returns: kubernets.V1PersistentVolume """ @abstractmethod def delete(slef, pv): """Delete a pv :param pv: kubernets.V1PersistentVolume """

commit_message:
Add cinder provision volume plugin

Change-Id: I77a33439a73ae08a439ba3671a7f7f7fcdc010f4
blueprint: implement-flex-volume-provisioning
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuxi-kubernetes refs/changes/38/489138/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from kubernetes import client as k8s_client from fuxi_kubernetes.common import constants from fuxi_kubernetes import exceptions from fuxi_kubernetes.provisioner.provision_plugins import provision_plugin from fuxi_kubernetes import utils class CinderProvisionPlugin(provision_plugin.ProvisionPlugin): def __init__(self): self._cinder_client = utils.get_cinder_client() self._supported_volume_access_modes = [ constants.READ_WRITE_ONCE] def provision(self, volume_option): access_modes = volume_option.pvc.spc.access_modes if not all([am in self._supported_volume_access_modes for am in access_modes]): raise exceptions.CreatePersistentVolumeException( 'Cinder volume', 'receive invalid access modes:%s' % str(access_modes)) if not access_modes: access_modes = self._supported_volume_access_modes volume = None try: volume = self._create_volume(volume_option) except Exception as ex: raise exceptions.CreatePersistentVolumeException( 'Cinder volume', 'create volume failed, %s' % str(ex)) return k8s_client.V1PersistentVolume( metadata=k8s_client.V1ObjectMeta( name=volume_option.pv_name, annotations={ constants.KUBERNETES_VOLUME_DYNAMICALLY_CREATED_BY_KEY: "external-cinder-dynamic-provisioner"} ), spec=k8s_client.V1PersistentVolumeSpec( persistent_volume_reclaim_policy=( volume_option.pv_reclaim_policy), access_modes=access_modes, capacity={ constants.PV_CAPACITY_STORAGE: str(volume.size)}, flex_volume=k8s_client.V1FlexVolumeSource( driver=constants.FLEX_VOLUME_DRIVER_CINDER, fs_type=volume_option.parameters.get('fstype', 'ext4'), options={ constants.CINDER_VOLUME_ATTR_VOLUME_ID: volume.id}, read_only=volume_option.parameters.get('read_only', False) ) ) ) def delete(self, pv): """Delete a pv :param pv: kubernetes.client.V1PersistentVolume """ volume_id = None try: volume_id = pv.spec.flex_volume.options.get( constants.CINDER_VOLUME_ATTR_VOLUME_ID) if volume_id: self._cinder_client.volumes.delete(volume_id) except Exception as ex: raise exceptions.DeletePersistentVolumeException( "Cinder volume, id=%s" % volume_id, str(ex)) def _create_volume(self, volume_option): params = volume_option.parameters return self._cinder_client.create( size=int(volume_option.pvc.spec.resources.requests.get( constants.PV_CAPACITY_STORAGE)), name=volume_option.pv_name, volume_type=params.get('volume_type'), availability_zone=params.get('availability_zone') )

commit_message:
Implement provisioner and deleter

provisioner: Watch PVC to provision volume for it.
deleter: Watch PV to delete the volume.

Change-Id: I5bb389ac721c61f990fc14caec975add25c26dbc
blueprint: implement-flex-volume-provisioning

commit_message:
Replace jsonutils by ujson

ujson is faster than jsonutils, and we do not need any fancy feature jsonutils
might offer.

Change-Id: I2d8e70da055777d58ca5e6718458dd5dcf294747

commit_message:
Add devstack plugin

With this plugin, it can setup an environment which runs a smallest set of
services, including Keystone, Cinder and FlexVolume plugin of Fuxi-kubernetes.
However, it does not setup services of Kubernetes. I will add it later.

Change-Id: Ic906cc69e996c386b98322ecdbbbdbb45c637f79

commit_message:
[WIP] Auto set UEFI mode for irmc-pxe boot interface

This commit will bring to auto set UEFI mode in BIOS before,
then perform to boot instance with boot_mode is uefi via
irmc-pxe interface.

Change-Id: Ia27a6635c2182a746a8c11738fdc0d6d3ce25abf

commit_message:
[WIP]Convert attaching volume from sync to async

For cinder provider with connector type 'openstack', volumes will be attached
to host one by one when creating multi-volume at the same time.
With this way, it will spend much time at waiting for attaching.
In this patch, this situation will be replaced with attaching volume asychronously.
Of course, this way is main for kvm hypervisor.

Change-Id: I4f8f05d240dfb6cc2dbdbe5b8c0c4189cfb4e290
blueprint: attaching-cinder-volume-asychronously

subject: Do not use "-y" for package install
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-01-02 09:22:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuxi/commit/fc75fb0ff8b00e0c56fbc62ecd7b92c80efcd700', 'message': 'Do not use \x93-y\x94 for package install

According to "code conventions" [1], do not use "-y" option.
Instead, use apt-get install package, yum install package,
or zypper install package.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/doc-contrib-guide/writing-style/code-conventions.html

commit_message:
Do not use "-y" for package install

According to "code conventions" [1], do not use "-y" option.
Instead, use apt-get install package, yum install package,
or zypper install package.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/doc-contrib-guide/writing-style/code-conventions.html

Change-Id: I9f0c371b4f61c7842ed46b9e1db9337b9549a3a1

commit_message:
Move legacy jobs to project

This patch implements first step in zuulv3 migration guide [1]:

Move jobs to fuxi repo

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/zuulv3.html#legacy-job-migration-details

Change-Id: Ia54f97f9798a286d705b808af4d6bf1baf6e5619

subject: Fix unit test failures
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-08-27 17:02:34.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuxi-kubernetes/commit/fb5c17888b987e64f4e0f8f56384b7ea7be0d1b0', 'message': 'Fix unit test failures

While running the gate it was observed that the unit
tests was trying to run python setup.py testr which
was failing.

So move the unit tests to stest like the rest of the
OpenStack projects.

commit_message:
Fix unit test failures

While running the gate it was observed that the unit
tests was trying to run python setup.py testr which
was failing.

So move the unit tests to stest like the rest of the
OpenStack projects.

Also adjust requirements to pass test gates.

Change-Id: I44f53db971506d9270e7cf8888f5bef2a53aa9c2
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chucks@redhat.com>

commit_message:
import zuul job settings from project-config

This is a mechanically generated patch to complete step 1 of moving
the zuul job settings out of project-config and into each project
repository.

Because there will be a separate patch on each branch, the branch
specifiers for branch-specific jobs have been removed.

Because this patch is generated by a script, there may be some
cosmetic changes to the layout of the YAML file(s) as the contents are
normalized.

See the python3-first goal document for details:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/stein/python3-first.html

commit_message:
Add get_by_cell_and_project() method to InstanceMappingList

Adds a new query method to query for instance_mappings in the provided
cell for the provided project_id.

Related to blueprint handling-down-cell

Change-Id: I4b4466de9160267c23b88c2b35673745fd989f4d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/56/591656/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @staticmethod @db_api.api_context_manager.reader def _get_by_cell_and_project_from_db(context, cell_id, project_id): return (context.session.query(api_models.InstanceMapping) .options(joinedload('cell_mapping')) .filter_by(cell_id=cell_id) .filter_by(project_id=project_id) .all()) @base.remotable_classmethod def get_by_cell_and_project(cls, context, cell_id, project_id): db_mappings = cls._get_by_cell_and_project_from_db(context, cell_id, project_id) return base.obj_make_list(context, cls(), objects.InstanceMapping, db_mappings)

commit_message:
Pin fog-openstack to < 0.3.0

With 0.3.1, fog-openstack renames much of its API, resulting in
errors such as:

  openstack_domain[default] (openstack-identity::registration line 69) had
  an error: NameError: uninitialized constant Fog::Identity::OpenStack

Let's stay below 0.3 for now.

Change-Id: Id3e9e6d8560ef5ffd9d28eedc0a2494722a2878f
(cherry picked from commit 0664bf29358ce16d85756d994751b4a3a37a6118)

commit_message:
BaseValidationAction

* Provides a base for additional actions whose effect on
  validation can be specified in the configuration
* Intended to be inherited from in plugins.
* Instructions are in docs

Change-Id: I5991425777b5216ec4501796f5f2733a55eb8ed2
Implements: blueprint base-validation-action
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/adjutant refs/changes/61/539061/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class BaseValidationAction(BaseAction): """Creates base for additional validation actions to be built on top A validation action is an action designed to be added in to a pre-existing task view and perform additional logic that may be specific to a deployment or set of plugins. The settings should be specified as under action settings stages: # At which stages to run the validation - pre_approve - post_approve - submit mark_invalid: False # Mark the whole task invalid if validation fails prevent_auto_approve: False # Prevent auto approval if validation fails auto_approve: False # Set autoapprove to true if the validation passes """ required = [] def _pre_approve(self): self.perform_action('pre_approve') def _post_approve(self): self.perform_action('post_approve') def _submit(self, data): self.perform_action('submit') def perform_action(self, stage): if stage in self.settings.get('stages'): valid = self._validate() if not valid and self.settings.get('mark_invalid'): self.action.valid = False self.action.save() return if not valid and self.settings.get('prevent_auto_approve'): self.set_auto_approve(False) if valid and self.settings.get('auto_approve'): self.set_auto_approve(True) self.action.valid = True self.action.save() def _validate(self): raise NotImplementedError

subject: Making instance/migration listing skipping down cells configurable
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-08-16 13:53:35.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/0624635e5e90fb2053c5a6338323ff4897d8b7aa', 'message': 'Making instance listing skipping down cells configurable

Presently if a cell is down, the instances in that cell are
skipped from results. Sometimes this may not be desirable for
operators as it may confuse the users who saw more instances in
their previous listing than now. This patch adds a new api config
option called instance_list_skip_down_cells which can be set to
False (True by default) if the operator desires to just return an
empty list altogether if the user has any instance in the down cell
instead of skipping.

Change-Id: Id749761c58d4e1bc001b745d49b6ff0f3732e133
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2018-08-27 12:56:09.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/becc09c9a82fb014e34a941fdc1dbfa23b04f543', 'message': 'Making instance listing skipping down cells configurable

Presently if a cell is down, the instances in that cell are
skipped from results. Sometimes this may not be desirable for
operators as it may confuse the users who saw more instances in
their previous listing than now. This patch adds a new api config
option called instance_list_skip_down_cells which can be set to
False (True by default) if the operator desires to just return an
API error altogether if the user has any instance in the down cell

commit_message:
Making instance/migration listing skipping down cells configurable

Presently if a cell is down, the instances in that cell are
skipped from results. Sometimes this may not be desirable for
operators as it may confuse the users who saw more instances in
their previous listing than now. This patch adds a new api config
option called list_records_by_skipping_down_cells which can be set to
False (True by default) if the operator desires to just return an
API error altogether if the user has any instance in the down cell
instead of skipping. This is essentially a configurable revert of
change I308b494ab07f6936bef94f4c9da45e9473e3534d for bug 1726301 so
that operators can opt into the 500 response behaviour during listing.

Change-Id: Id749761c58d4e1bc001b745d49b6ff0f3732e133
Related-Bug: #1726301

commit_message:
Conditionally install build packages

Disable installation of the -devel build packages by default since
they are only needed on the repo containers to build the MariaDB
client wheels.

Change-Id: I1938233a88dcd824c19390cf4191670119f38912

commit_message:
Make neutron-fullstack-python36 job voting

The neutron-fullstack-python3[56] job has a record of stability at least
as good as the neutron-fullstack job at this point for the past 2 weeks
[1].  Make it a voting check and add it to the gate queue.

[1] http://graphite.openstack.org/render/?width=1242&height=553&_salt=1533933299.32&from=-14days&drawNullAsZero=true&lineMode=connected&connectedLimit=&areaMode=all&yStep=1&title=neutron-fullstack-python35%20job%20data&target=stats_counts.zuul.tenant.openstack.pipeline.check.project.git_openstack_org.openstack_neutron.master.job.neutron-fullstack-python35.SUCCESS&target=stats_counts.zuul.tenant.openstack.pipeline.check.project.git_openstack_org.openstack_neutron.master.job.neutron-fullstack-python35.FAILURE

Change-Id: I6e647cb502485bef8fed55046a2cd7778eb64ab2

commit_message:
Nix update_instance_allocation, _allocate_for_instance

A previous change [1] removed the only usage of SchedulerReportClient
method update_instance_allocation, which itself was the only user of the
_allocate_for_instance method. Remove both of these methods and their
test artifacts.

commit_message:
Use role defaults for lxc_cache_prep_timeout

In https://review.openstack.org/523525 the default value was
changed for SuSE and CentOS to be higher, but the value was
also overridden using role vars which have a high precedence.

This patch ensures that the value uses the role defaults to
ensure it has the lowest precedence. It also changes the reno
to ensure that the change in default is communicated.

The increased timeout will have no real effect on gating, but
will benefit installations where the mirror is a bit slow.

Change-Id: I41a68313d1841d14001acca591db5c5638e53ffc

pattern match to include this case.

commit_message:
Remove galera_client meta-dependency

Given that pymysql is pure python and has no C binding
dependencies, we no longer need the role to install the
MariaDB client libraries.

Change-Id: I1414eb49caab3cc8e18e2a330c6127912255e8e3

commit_message:
Remove tempest testing

The stable/ocata branches are now in extended maintenance, so we
no longer expect to do releases from them. The tempest tests are
somewhat broken at this time, and this old code is difficult to
troubleshoot to fix it. As such, we remove the tempest tests,
leaving only a convergence test and rely on anyone still using
the old branch to resolve issues as they come up.

Change-Id: Ie0ef3c6194b64df6f25803e81ac0833f4d42984c

commit_message:
import zuul job settings from project-config

This is a mechanically generated patch to complete step 1 of moving
the zuul job settings out of project-config and into each project
repository.

Because there will be a separate patch on each branch, the branch
specifiers for branch-specific jobs have been removed.

Because this patch is generated by a script, there may be some
cosmetic changes to the layout of the YAML file(s) as the contents are
normalized.

See the python3-first goal document for details:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/stein/python3-first.html

Change-Id: I574ddd2d97bd9ec1dfec05ef088e70068d276fb2
Story: #2002586
Task: #24319

commit_message:
Drop extra Ceph messages

Ceph has a problem where logs that were introduced which are
debug messages are logged as normal.  They cause a lot of extra
useless messages and overloading ELK cluster

This was fixed in 12.2.9 which is not out yet, so let's work
around it for now by avoiding shipping it.

Change-Id: I36a503b7380ce62c65570232a18d2179a98ecfa1

commit_message:
Fix very misleading error message in policy_authority module

This patch set changes the wording of a highly misleading
error message that is raised in an exception when there is a
failure trying to read or open a policy file. The message is
changed to be accurate.

Change-Id: I8a5fe80a2dc134e602b0324096061a183884f35a

commit_message:
Add tempest-slow job to run the tempest slow tests

By default, tempest-full jobs don't run the "slow" tests
which test useful things like encrypted volumes, swap
volume, etc. The slow tests aren't part of the default
tempest run since they can be, well, slow.

Tempest has tempest-slow job now which run all the slow
tagged tests.[1]

Detailed discussion on ML[2].

[1] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/tempest/tree/.zuul.yaml#n146
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-May/130394.html

Conflicts:
      .zuul.yaml

NOTE(mriedem): The conflict is due to not having change
Ife046b91c96dd300e8c46125b75623d8e12b8da3 in Queens.

Related-Bug: #1783405

Change-Id: I5cb829beebcc59de682cba927f5b01793ec70d00
(cherry picked from commit f6390f71ff96a1ea6f4315253ef61e0a0c2ef980)
